title: Jun 05, 2024 — Catastrophic failure of the BSFM
description: On June 5, 2024, the Bearspaw South Feedermain (BSFM) suffered a catastrophic failure.

title: Immediate response — AE engaged for forensic investigation
description: Immediately following the rupture, The City requested Associated Engineering (AE) to undertake a forensic investigation of the failed pipe, considering subsequent information gained during exposure of additional distressed pipes.

title: Exposure — ruptured segment excavated and examined
description: Following work by City crews to fully expose the ruptured pipe segment, representatives from The City, AE, Corrpro, and Pure met on-site to inspect the damage and document conditions.

title: Jun 07, 2024 — Corrpro contracted for corrosion assessment
description: On June 7, 2024, Corrpro Canada, Inc. (Corrpro) was contracted by Associate Engineering to perform a corrosion assessment.

title: Jun 08, 2024 — On-site inspection of pipe damage
description: Representatives from The City (multiple departments), AE, Corrpro, and Pure met on-site on June 8 and conducted an inspection of the pipe damage.

title: Observed failure — widespread prestress wire breaks
description: Across the rupture (~2 m), every visible prestressed wire was broken (estimated ~200 broken wires), with fracture appearances including general corrosion and brittle and ductile modes.

title: Assessment — Pure contracted for electromagnetic inspections
description: Following the June 5 rupture, The City contracted Pure to inspect the C301 portion of the BSFM using robotic and free-swimming electromagnetic inspection tools.

title: Inspection findings — 239 additional distressed pipes
description: Electromagnetic inspections revealed a total of 239 distressed pipes in addition to the pipe that ruptured, with distressed pipes defined as pipe lengths having one or more wraps of prestressed wires broken.

title: Phase 1 repairs — five distressed pipes addressed
description: AE observed the Phase 1 repair program to replace/rehabilitate five pipes identified as distressed in the electromagnetic inspections undertaken subsequent to the initial break.

title: Pipe examinations — hydroblasting reveals more damage than EM indicated
description: Exhumed pipes were examined after mortar removal (hydroblasting). Observations indicate some wires were electrically continuous in-situ but corroded to the point they broke during handling, explaining why electromagnetic inspection may report conservative pipe condition.

title: Jun 11, 2024 — Corrpro report (referenced by addendum)
description: This report is an addendum to the previous Corrpro report dated June 11, 2024.

title: Jun 21, 2024 — Additional Corrpro investigation
description: Corrpro personnel performed an additional investigation on June 21, 2024.

title: Jun 28, 2024 — Corrpro addendum letter date
description: Corrpro addendum/letter dated June 28, 2024 (referenced in the corrosion assessment addendum section header).

title: Soil sampling — rupture-site soil samples not reliable
description: Soil samples taken at the original rupture site were not considered reliable due to the volume of water released and were not included in the report’s soil assessment.

title: Soils — chlorides/resistivity correlate with pipe distress
description: The report describes a strong correlation between pipe distress, elevated chlorides, and low soil resistivity, with elevated chlorides believed to be related to road de-icing activities.

title: Non-contributors — pressure transients, pump ops, live load, stray current
description: Findings indicate pump/system operations and transients did not contribute; live loading is not believed to be a factor; and stray current induced corrosion does not appear to be present.

title: Materials — corrosion, pitting, brittle fractures, SCC/HE evidence
description: Lab and field observations describe severe pitting/corrosion and brittle wire failures, with evidence of Stress Corrosion Cracking and Hydrogen Embrittlement associated with chloride penetration and/or microcracking of mortar.

title: Probable cause — prestress wire failures driven by mortar compromise
description: The probable cause is loss of structural integrity primarily through prestress wire failure, with microcracking or mortar damage allowing moisture/corrosive soils to interact with wires, leading to SCC and/or HE and brittle failures.

title: Sep 03, 2024 — EM inspection results issued
description: Issued to Associated Engineering on September 3, 2024.
sourceSection: Appendix B — Pure EM Inspection Results
